document.text: from public taxes. In 1870, this in novation met with considerable op position. Good judgment finally prevaield and the County Public School System was begun on a very modest scale. The first public school in this county was located in a log cabin near the Old Court House. The first teacher in the public school system was J. H. Featherston. The first County Superintendent of Schools was C. H. Chilton, 1870- 1881. He was succeeded by J. B. Bristow, who continued in office un til 1885. Mr. Chilton returned to office in that year and served until 1897. Sucessors in office were J. K. Hannah, 1897-1913 N. R. Feather ston, 1913-1926 and J. A. Burke, 1926 to date, The first public school house built with county funds was erected at Hurtsville. Other school structures were added as fast as funds from school taxes made these accomoda tions possible. Mr. N. R. Featherston, in his his tory of Appomattox County, re ports that the school term in the early days of the system was five months. Teachers average monthly salary was 25.00. In 1908, Professor Lindsay Craw ley was apointed principal of the high school at Appomattox. The frame building housing the high school stood on the lot where the present T. W. Moses residence is located. There were three teachers and 160. students. Funds allocated by the legislature in this year, with matching donations by private citi zens, financed the building of a new high school at the present site. Appomattox High School open ed in September, 1909, with the im posing name of Tenth Congression al District High School. Our public school system has made great advances in the years since 1909. In the past ten years alone, we have seen the construc tion of a new and up-to-date agri cultural vocational building at the high school addition of a hew gym nasium construction of the Carver- Price High School and elementary school for Negroes, and the build ing of the new elementary school in the town of Appomattox. For the current session, total enrollment in county public schools is 2,300 pupils, with 93 teachers.

With a library of more than 5,000 volumes, audio - visual equipment and a growing guid ance program, the school has a bright future. From time to time salaries were discussed. In 1S72 the County Board adopted a salary sohedule A teacher holding a full certi ficate to receive 35 per month. A teacher holding an Inter mediate certificate to receive 25 per month. A teacher holding a Primary certificate to receive 20 per month. Teachers who had no certifi cate received less than 20. Mr. Chilton, as have other county superintendent, made a strong effort to help the teachers im prove their professional prepa ration. At the beginning of the school system in our county our efficient County Superintendent, Capt. C. H. Chilton, organized a County Teachers Institute, which met under a constitution and by-laws adopted by the soc iety for instruction in pedagogics regularly every month. The pro- meter of all school work found here a wide and inviting field. Captain Chilton did a good Work in this direction. Textbooks w e r e regularly studied to recite in these teach ers meetings in connection with recitations on theory and prac tice of teaching. Young teachers found aid and stimulus to their work. The more experienced be- oame more deeply impressed with the dignity, importanoe and responsibility of their avo cation. None but madmen and fools could ever aim to suppress such a helpful institution and adjunct to our admirable sys tem of free education. Gradually Capt. Chilton less ened the number of meetings, unfit an annual Institute was all that necessity seem to him to require. Even then steps to re quire teachers to attend had to be taken. As toe years passed a committee made up of the sup erintendent and teachers plann ed the Institute. The board was foresighted enough to recognize the value to be derived from the Virginia Journal, so in 1907 it was sent to each teacher for six months at the boards expense. The board did this on other occasion also. It was agreed to try to induce all the teachers who could do so to attend the Teach ers Meeting in Roanoke, Octo ber 5, 1907, and to receive their usual pay during the time lost from school.  Many teachers, maybe all, had to go to the Court House each year to take examinations for two days. Those examina tions were far different from what most of us would give to day. The Board granted a 2.50 per month raise in salary to those who attended the State Normals Summer School. The early schools were heated by fireplaces if heated at all. The big boys, and there must have been big boys in every school since the board allowed people up to 25 years of age to attend without paying tuition, went Into near-by woods and either broke up or cut wood which they dragged or brought. As money became available the board hired people to deliver wood to school to be cut. Later cut or sawed wood was deliver- jed. The big Girls swept the one - room sohool. document.text: Retirement, to a lot of people means long, lazy days of doing nothing. Not so with Miss Harriett A. Chilton of Falls S u rc h . Va. A native of Appomattox County. Miss Chilton grew up near Spout Spring and graduated from Appomattox High School in 1929 . She attended Madison College and served in the Womens Army Corps in World War II, being stationed in the Southwest Pacific area. Miss Chilton is the daughter of the late William C. and Jemima Chilton and granddaughter of Chapman Hunter Chilton who was Principal of Union Aca demy near Spout Spring in the 1860s and became the first Superintendent of Schools in the County when the public school system was begun in 1870. With a background such as hers it is only natural that Miss Chiltons love of Appomat tox County and its people runs deep. Being a lover of history, since her retirement from Federal government service, Miss Chil ton has been doing historical and genealogical research as a hobby. She has found time to write and her books include Abstract of Appomattox Quar terly Meeting Conference of the Methodist Church 1861-1875, and the Register of Old Concord Presbyterian Church
